A Test Book Catherine Dalzell 2022-09-06 1 The problem You have an awesome code project hosted on GitHub. You launch into an explanation of how it works in your Readme.md. You push to GitHub only to discover that the site has truncated your magnum opus half way through. You now need to link to a separate web site for the complete documentation. There is a simpler way. Include your documentation in a folder of your repo, and use bookdown and GitHub pages to display the result in a classy format. No need to know HTML or CSS – just a bit of Markdown and a willingness to open RStudio.

2 Using bookdown R package bookdown allows organizing and compiling several Rmarkdown (or simple markdown files) into a book-like website complete with table of contents and chapter links. The author, Yihui Xie, illustrates the results in his bookdown formatted documentation. Bookdown has a lot of options, but I’m just going to focus on the basics required to host a multi-page document on github as supplementary documentation for a repo. 2.1 Pre-requisites Know how to install R and RStudio. Know enough about R to install a package Know enough about RStudio to create an RMarkdown document. Have a GitHub account and not be afraid to use it. 2.2 What’s R got to do with it? bookdown happens to be an R package, which is why we need R and RStudio (the R IDE). If you want to analyse data in your project using R, you can both run and publish the results from the same script, using RMarkdown. bookdown lets you write a complete data science textbook on the results, if you are so minded. But fear not. RMarkdown is a superset of Markdown, and bookdown can be used to write anything you like with or without supporting R code. 2.3 Stuff we can do 2.3.1 \(\LaTeX\) is supported. \[ e^{i\pi}= -1 \] 2.3.2 Plots and calculations summary(cars) speed dist Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 3rd Qu.:19.0 3rd Qu.: 56.00 Max. :25.0 Max. :120.00 plot(pressure)
3 The Instructions 3.1 Document structure 3.2 knit and publish

3 The Instructions But back to bookdown … Install R and RStudio In the console of RStudio, enter install.packages("bookdown") to install the package. Create your repo, say myRepo and create an R Project based on that repo. Create a folder in myRepo called docs, say. Your book is going to live in docs, allowing the rest of your repo to contain an awesome project of some kind. Create an Rmd file called index.Rmd in docs. An RMarkdown document begins with some yaml lines. The default that comes with RStudio looks like this: title: "My Title" author: "Catherine Dalzell" date: "2022-09-06" output: html_document This yaml instructs knitr to render the document in the usual way. We need to change this if we want to get bookdown output. This simple example works: title: "A Test Book" author: "Your Name" date: "2022-09-06" site: bookdown::bookdown_site output: bookdown::gitbook documentclass: book link-citations: yes github-repo: GitHub_username/myRepo description: "A simple Bookdown demo" There are other options, but this will get the job done if you want to host on GitHub using GitHub Pages. Note that the repo name is what it says, not myRepo/docs, or wherever you are storing you documentation. 3.1 Document structure Major headings in markdown are noted with a single hash #. In bookdown, a major heading signifies the start of a new chapter. Double hashes create subsections; these also get links in the table of contents. Triple hashes do not show up in the TOC, but they display in the body of the document as minor headings. It is possible to build a bookdown book from a collection of Rmd files, but the simplest way to get a book is to write everything in one long Rmd file, using major headings to define the chapters. 3.2 knit and publish click the Knit button in RStudio to render the book. It should display in RStudio’s default browser. You should now see a folder called _book in the docs When you like what you see and have finished your edits, push the entire project to Github. Check your repo on GitHub. The files that contain your book will be there, but they will not display as a static web site. We can fix that. Open the settings of your repo and click on pages. It’s on the left hand side of the page. 10. Under source, select GitHub Actions followed by Static HTML. 11. You will be taken to a configuration document. configuration The only thing you need to change is the path entry. The default is .. Change this to the folder that contains your bookdown output. In my case, this is docs/_book. Press the big green button to commit your change and pull it back down to your local repo. Wait a moment and then check under settings -> pages again. You should see something like this: final step GitHub informs you that your site is live at [book_url]. To make your book easy to find, copy this url and link to it from your Readme. You now have beautiful documentation to supplement your awesome project!
